content: "http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/30829066/" Now Congress is moving to limit the penalties on riskier borrowers, who have become a prime source of billions of dollars in fee revenue for the industry. And to make up for lost income, the card companies are going after those people with sterling credit. Banks are expected to look at reviving annual fees, curtailing cash-back and other rewards programs and charging interest immediately on a purchase instead of allowing a grace period of weeks, according to bank officials and trade groups.

title: Responsible credit card users Get ready to pay more

content: My mom had one credit card while I was growing up. She used it twice. The first time was when we were traveling and the car broke down. The second time was when our water heater burst and flooded the basement. Both times, she paid it off immediately. I learned good financial lessons from my mother - a lifelong Democrat and moderate-liberal, for those who are curious. If you don't have the money, don't spend it. (For that matter... My father was the one who bankrupted the family by taking out piggyback loans on a second mortgage and spending on God-knows-what, including plane trips and (as we found out) hookers. Oh, and Daddy was the "good" conservative, ultra-religious Republican. Thank goodness I learned finances from my mother.) So my mother owned one credit card that she almost never used, and I took it one step further. I've NEVER owned a credit card. The only debt I've ever had was student loans, which are almost paid off and were never late. I bought my cars in cash, and I won't buy a home until I can cover most of it in a down payment. Do I feel bad that "good" credit card users whose rates will be hiked up? Perhaps a little bit. But seriously people... do you think you get something for nothing? The way we use credit cards in today's society is insane. I'd be happy to see people completely get away from credit cards. Screw the skymiles. The "rewards" come out of something else. This is a closed system (a big one, yes, but still a closed system), and nothing is free. If we're so far gone that people can't survive without credit cards, what does that say about our society?

Whatever charges I run up, I pay off monthly anyway, so it doesn't apply to me, or to other responsible card users. This legislation is good. It's a good start.

content: What? REad the link more carefully. I haven't read it, but I don't believe responsible credit card users pay more. Even if the information in the link is true, responsible credit card users still get rewarded in other ways. Employers do credit checks. A credit score of over 700 is not automatic: you must have a history of borrowing, from the bank, paying bills on time, and paying credit card bills on time. So when 2 people have equal qualifications for the job, the person with the credit score of over 700 gets the job. And the person with the lousy credit score doesn't get anything. So, the amount of money you lose by not getting the job will dwarf the amount of money you save as a risky borrower. As an unemployed person with no history of borrowing, no experience in my field of study, I need the credit card companies to raise my credit score. No credit card company will give me a credit card except the ones that charge over 10% interest. I can live with that, as it takes money to make money (I don't mind paying an extra 10% interest in return for the credit score i'll need to get a job). On the personal side of the business of employers checking credit scores, I believe its all about one question: "where's the money"? That is why when College graduates look for work in big law firms, you must have graduated from an ABA approved law school; not necessarily because the education was better, but because they are more expensive. Again: Where is the money, employers want to know. And when College graduates look for work, the College graduate who graduated from a big University with no financial aid packages will get the job. Why: because if you graduated from a city public college with financial aid packages, that means you didn't pay for your education, and you have no way of showing employers how you overcome obstacles in life. But there's really only 1 key issue: Where's the money?. quote: Originally posted by ss_287: "http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/30829066/" Now Congress is moving to limit the penalties on riskier borrowers, who have become a prime source of billions of dollars in fee revenue for the industry. And to make up for lost income, the card companies are going after those people with sterling credit. Banks are expected to look at reviving annual fees, curtailing cash-back and other rewards programs and charging interest immediately on a purchase instead of allowing a grace period of weeks, according to bank officials and trade groups.
quote: Originally posted by ss_287: "http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/30829066/" Now Congress is moving to limit the penalties on riskier borrowers, who have become a prime source of billions of dollars in fee revenue for the industry. And to make up for lost income, the card companies are going after those people with sterling credit. Banks are expected to look at reviving annual fees, curtailing cash-back and other rewards programs and charging interest immediately on a purchase instead of allowing a grace period of weeks, according to bank officials and trade groups.
reply: What? REad the link more carefully. I haven't read it, but I don't believe responsible credit card users pay more. Even if the information in the link is true, responsible credit card users still get rewarded in other ways. Employers do credit checks. A credit score of over 700 is not automatic: you must have a history of borrowing, from the bank, paying bills on time, and paying credit card bills on time. So when 2 people have equal qualifications for the job, the person with the credit score of over 700 gets the job. And the person with the lousy credit score doesn't get anything. So, the amount of money you lose by not getting the job will dwarf the amount of money you save as a risky borrower. As an unemployed person with no history of borrowing, no experience in my field of study, I need the credit card companies to raise my credit score. No credit card company will give me a credit card except the ones that charge over 10% interest. I can live with that, as it takes money to make money (I don't mind paying an extra 10% interest in return for the credit score i'll need to get a job). On the personal side of the business of employers checking credit scores, I believe its all about one question: "where's the money"? That is why when College graduates look for work in big law firms, you must have graduated from an ABA approved law school; not necessarily because the education was better, but because they are more expensive. Again: Where is the money, employers want to know. And when College graduates look for work, the College graduate who graduated from a big University with no financial aid packages will get the job. Why: because if you graduated from a city public college with financial aid packages, that means you didn't pay for your education, and you have no way of showing employers how you overcome obstacles in life. But there's really only 1 key issue: Where's the money?.

content: UPDATE!!!!!!! Barack Obama considering panel to protect consumers with credit cards, mortgages, financial products. The proposal could set off a turf war among federal agencies such as the Securities and Exchange Commission and the various bank regulatory agencies. There was also a discussion of the proposal at a dinner Tuesday at the Treasury Department attended by Treasury Secretary Timothy Geithner and Lawrence Summers, director of the president's National Economic Council. Rest of the story is here: "http://www.nydailynews.com/money/2009/05/20/2009-05-20_president_obama_considering_a_panel_to_protect_consumers_with_credit_cards_mortg.html" "A government big enough to give you everything you want, is strong enough to take everything you have." ~ Gerald Ford

content: I use my Citibank card for just about everything, pay it off every month, and accrue the air miles. I don't fly that much, so I would have no problem cancelling my card. If I can escape any scheme that makes me pay for someone's financial irresponsibility, I'll do it. "The World's Finest"

content: quote: Originally posted by ss_287: "http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/30829066/" Now Congress is moving to limit the penalties on riskier borrowers, who have become a prime source of billions of dollars in fee revenue for the industry. And to make up for lost income, the card companies are going after those people with sterling credit. Banks are expected to look at reviving annual fees, curtailing cash-back and other rewards programs and charging interest immediately on a purchase instead of allowing a grace period of weeks, according to bank officials and trade groups. Yes, the impact on those who use credit wisely and responsibly will no doubt be negative. But I suspect that most of the crying came from those who didn't!
quote: Originally posted by ss_287: "http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/30829066/" Now Congress is moving to limit the penalties on riskier borrowers, who have become a prime source of billions of dollars in fee revenue for the industry. And to make up for lost income, the card companies are going after those people with sterling credit. Banks are expected to look at reviving annual fees, curtailing cash-back and other rewards programs and charging interest immediately on a purchase instead of allowing a grace period of weeks, according to bank officials and trade groups.
reply: Yes, the impact on those who use credit wisely and responsibly will no doubt be negative. But I suspect that most of the crying came from those who didn't!

title: Responsible credit card users Get ready to pay more

content: My mom had one credit card while I was growing up. She used it twice. The first time was when we were traveling and the car broke down. The second time was when our water heater burst and flooded the basement. Both times, she paid it off immediately. I learned good financial lessons from my mother - a lifelong Democrat and moderate-liberal, for those who are curious. If you don't have the money, don't spend it. (For that matter... My father was the one who bankrupted the family by taking out piggyback loans on a second mortgage and spending on God-knows-what, including plane trips and (as we found out) hookers. Oh, and Daddy was the "good" conservative, ultra-religious Republican. Thank goodness I learned finances from my mother.) So my mother owned one credit card that she almost never used, and I took it one step further. I've NEVER owned a credit card. The only debt I've ever had was student loans, which are almost paid off and were never late. I bought my cars in cash, and I won't buy a home until I can cover most of it in a down payment. Do I feel bad that "good" credit card users whose rates will be hiked up? Perhaps a little bit. But seriously people... do you think you get something for nothing? The way we use credit cards in today's society is insane. I'd be happy to see people completely get away from credit cards. Screw the skymiles. The "rewards" come out of something else. This is a closed system (a big one, yes, but still a closed system), and nothing is free. If we're so far gone that people can't survive without credit cards, what does that say about our society?

content: We already have been raped by credit card company's for them extending credit to those who can't afford it. If were being treated fairly by them, there would be no need for this legislation. Whatever charges I run up, I pay off monthly anyway, so it doesn't apply to me, or to other responsible card users. This legislation is good. It's a good start.
reply: We already have been raped by credit card company's for them extending credit to those who can't afford it. If were being treated fairly by them, there would be no need for this legislation. Whatever charges I run up, I pay off monthly anyway, so it doesn't apply to me, or to other responsible card users. This legislation is good. It's a good start.
title: Responsible credit card users Get ready to pay more

content: What? REad the link more carefully. I haven't read it, but I don't believe responsible credit card users pay more. Even if the information in the link is true, responsible credit card users still get rewarded in other ways. Employers do credit checks. A credit score of over 700 is not automatic: you must have a history of borrowing, from the bank, paying bills on time, and paying credit card bills on time. So when 2 people have equal qualifications for the job, the person with the credit score of over 700 gets the job. And the person with the lousy credit score doesn't get anything. So, the amount of money you lose by not getting the job will dwarf the amount of money you save as a risky borrower. As an unemployed person with no history of borrowing, no experience in my field of study, I need the credit card companies to raise my credit score. No credit card company will give me a credit card except the ones that charge over 10% interest. I can live with that, as it takes money to make money (I don't mind paying an extra 10% interest in return for the credit score i'll need to get a job). On the personal side of the business of employers checking credit scores, I believe its all about one question: "where's the money"? That is why when College graduates look for work in big law firms, you must have graduated from an ABA approved law school; not necessarily because the education was better, but because they are more expensive. Again: Where is the money, employers want to know. And when College graduates look for work, the College graduate who graduated from a big University with no financial aid packages will get the job. Why: because if you graduated from a city public college with financial aid packages, that means you didn't pay for your education, and you have no way of showing employers how you overcome obstacles in life. But there's really only 1 key issue: Where's the money?. quote: Originally posted by ss_287: "http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/30829066/" Now Congress is moving to limit the penalties on riskier borrowers, who have become a prime source of billions of dollars in fee revenue for the industry. And to make up for lost income, the card companies are going after those people with sterling credit. Banks are expected to look at reviving annual fees, curtailing cash-back and other rewards programs and charging interest immediately on a purchase instead of allowing a grace period of weeks, according to bank officials and trade groups.

Banks are expected to look at reviving annual fees, curtailing cash-back and other rewards programs and charging interest immediately on a purchase instead of allowing a grace period of weeks, according to bank officials and trade groups.
reply: What? REad the link more carefully. I haven't read it, but I don't believe responsible credit card users pay more. Even if the information in the link is true, responsible credit card users still get rewarded in other ways. Employers do credit checks. A credit score of over 700 is not automatic: you must have a history of borrowing, from the bank, paying bills on time, and paying credit card bills on time. So when 2 people have equal qualifications for the job, the person with the credit score of over 700 gets the job. And the person with the lousy credit score doesn't get anything. So, the amount of money you lose by not getting the job will dwarf the amount of money you save as a risky borrower. As an unemployed person with no history of borrowing, no experience in my field of study, I need the credit card companies to raise my credit score. No credit card company will give me a credit card except the ones that charge over 10% interest. I can live with that, as it takes money to make money (I don't mind paying an extra 10% interest in return for the credit score i'll need to get a job). On the personal side of the business of employers checking credit scores, I believe its all about one question: "where's the money"? That is why when College graduates look for work in big law firms, you must have graduated from an ABA approved law school; not necessarily because the education was better, but because they are more expensive. Again: Where is the money, employers want to know. And when College graduates look for work, the College graduate who graduated from a big University with no financial aid packages will get the job. Why: because if you graduated from a city public college with financial aid packages, that means you didn't pay for your education, and you have no way of showing employers how you overcome obstacles in life. But there's really only 1 key issue: Where's the money?.

content: UPDATE!!!!!!! Barack Obama considering panel to protect consumers with credit cards, mortgages, financial products. The proposal could set off a turf war among federal agencies such as the Securities and Exchange Commission and the various bank regulatory agencies. There was also a discussion of the proposal at a dinner Tuesday at the Treasury Department attended by Treasury Secretary Timothy Geithner and Lawrence Summers, director of the president's National Economic Council. Rest of the story is here: "http://www.nydailynews.com/money/2009/05/20/2009-05-20_president_obama_considering_a_panel_to_protect_consumers_with_credit_cards_mortg.html" "A government big enough to give you everything you want, is strong enough to take everything you have." ~ Gerald Ford
